This refers to any person in this situation, not to a specific man. Use a natural expression in your language. Alternate translation: [If someone] or [When anyone]

Here, **his hand reaches** is a common expression meaning that someone prospers or becomes financially able. Use a natural expression in your language that communicates this meaning. Alternate translation: [but he becomes prosperous] or [but he earns enough money]
The word “money” is left out but understood. You could supply this word if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and he finds enough money to buy back his property]

text: he shall calculate the years since its sale, repay the balance to the man to whom he sold it, and return to his property.

translation_challenges.note: This refers to the number of years remaining until the next Year of Jubilee, which determines the value of the land based on expected crops. Alternate translation: [the number of years left until the Year of Jubilee] or [how many growing seasons remain]
This means he will return to his family land. Alternate translation: [and he will get his family property back] or [and his land will be returned to him]

text: But if he cannot obtain enough to repay him, what he sold will remain in possession of the buyer until the Year of Jubilee. In the Jubilee, however, it is to be released, so that he may return to his property.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this in [25:26](../25/26.md). Alternate translation: [But if he cannot earn enough money]

The words “money” and “land” are left out but understood. You could supply these words in your translation if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [But if he cannot find enough money to buy back his land]

Here, the land is spoken of as if it were a person who could **go out**. Use a natural way in your language to express that the land will return to its original owner. Alternate translation: [The land will be returned] or [The ownership of the land will revert]
Here, **it** refers to the land. Alternate translation: [the land]

text: If a man sells a house in a walled city, he retains his right of redemption until a full year after its sale; during that year it may be redeemed.

translation_challenges.note: This refers to any person in this situation, not a specific man. Use a natural way to express this in your language. Alternate translation: [And someone] or [And anyone]
In some languages, **house** and **dwelling** may be redundant. If your language would not use a phrase like this, you could simplify it. Alternate translation: [a house] or [a home]

Here, **days shall be its redemption** means that there is a specific time period for redeeming the property. Use a natural way in your language to express this time limit. Alternate translation: [The owner has only one year to buy it back] or [It can be redeemed only during the first year after it is sold]

text: If it is not redeemed by the end of a full year, then the house in the walled city is permanently transferred to its buyer and his descendants. It is not to be released in the Jubilee.

translation_challenges.note: If your language does not use a passive form like **it is not redeemed**, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [If the owner does not buy it back] or [If no one redeems it]
Here, **it** refers to the house. Alternate translation: [the house is … redeemed]
See how you translated similar phrases in [25:23](../25/23.md).
See how you translated this expression in [25:28](../25/28.md). Alternate translation: [It will not be returned]

text: But houses in villages with no walls around them are to be considered as open fields. They may be redeemed, and they shall be released in the Jubilee.

translation_challenges.note: This refers to **houses** in general that are not in walled cities, not a specific house. Use a natural way in your language to express this general category. Alternate translation: [But any house of] or [All houses in]

This describes villages without protective walls around them. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express this more simply. Alternate translation: [unwalled villages] or [villages without walls]
This means these houses are considered part of the agricultural land. Alternate translation: [as part of the fields of]
This means these properties can be bought back. Alternate translation: [These houses can be redeemed] or [People can buy back these houses]
See how you translated this expression in [25:28](../25/28.md). Alternate translation: [it must be returned]

Here these words are singular but refer to multiple houses. If the singular forms of these pronouns would not be natural in your language, you could use plural forms in your translation. Alternate translation: [to them] and [they shall go out]

text: As for the cities of the Levites, the Levites always have the right to redeem their houses in the cities they possess.

translation_challenges.note: This word introduces a new topic about the Levites special rights. Use a natural way in your language to introduce a new but related topic. Alternate translation: [As for the cities of] or [Regarding the cities of]
This means the Levites always have the right to buy back their houses. Alternate translation: [the Levites may always redeem] or [the Levites have a permanent right to buy back]

text: So whatever belongs to the Levites may be redeemed—a house sold in a city they possess—and must be released in the Jubilee, because the houses in the cities of the Levites are their possession among the Israelites.

translation_challenges.note: This refers to property that a Levite might buy back. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could state this explicitly. Alternate translation: [Any property a Levite could buy back]

In many languages it might be more natural to drop the second **and**. Use a natural way in your language to connect these two statements. Alternate translation: [Any property a Levite could buy back, it will return to its original owner]
See how you translated this expression in [25:28](../25/28.md). Alternate translation: [it must be returned to its original owner]

This could mean: 1) “the sale of a house in a city” or 2) “the sale of a house and a city.” You should follow how your local major language translations understand this phrase. Alternate translation: [the sale of a house in a city]

Here **it** is singular but refers to multiple houses. See how you translated this in [25:31](../25/31.md). Alternate translation: [for the houses of the cities of the Levites, they are their possessions]

text: But the open pastureland around their cities may not be sold, for this is their permanent possession.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated similar phrases in [25:30](../25/30.md) or [25:32](../25/32.md). Alternate translation: [is a permanent possession]

text: Now if your countryman becomes destitute and cannot support himself among you, then you are to help him as you would a foreigner or stranger, so that he can continue to live among you.

translation_challenges.note: This introduces a hypothetical situation. Use a natural way in your language to introduce a situation that could happen. Alternate translation: [Suppose] or [When]

Here, **your brother** refers to any fellow Israelite, not only literal brothers. Use a natural way in your language to express this relationship. Alternate translation: [your fellow Israelite] or [your countryman]

Here, **brother** refers to any Israelite, whether male or female. Use a word in your language that makes this clear. Alternate translation: [your fellow Israelite] or [any countryman or countrywoman]

Here, **his hand wavers** is a common expression that means he becomes poor or struggles financially. If this phrase does not mean this in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he becomes unable to support himself] or [and he falls into financial difficulty]

Here, **then you shall strengthen** refers specifically to providing financial or material support. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state this explicitly. Alternate translation: [help him by providing what he needs] or [support him financially]

text: Do not take any interest or profit from him, but fear your God, that your countryman may live among you.

translation_challenges.note: Here, fearing God is given as the reason for not charging interest and letting your brother live with you. If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Because you must fear your God, you shall not take interest or profit from him, and your brother shall live with you] or [Since you must honor your God, do not charge him interest or profit, and let your brother live with you]

text: You must not lend him your silver at interest or sell him your food for profit.

translation_challenges.note: Here the verse expresses a single idea by repeating it in a way that the middle parts match (**interest** and **profit**) and the outside parts (**silver** and **food**) match. The two parts emphasize that you should not profit from lending anything to a poor person. If your language has a natural way to express this kind of emphasis through repetition, you could use it. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine the ideas and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [Do not charge interest when you lend money or food to him] or [You must not make any profit when you lend either silver or food to him]

text: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan and to be your God.

translation_challenges.note: Throughout this verse, **you** is plural and refers to all the Israelites. Use the plural form of “you” in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Alternate translation: [all of you … to all of you … to all of you]

text: If a countryman among you becomes destitute and sells himself to you, then you must not force him into slave labor.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this conditional phrase in [25:35](../25/35.md). Alternate translation: [Suppose]
See how you translated this term in [25:35](../25/35.md). Alternate translation: [your fellow Israelite]

The words **sells himself** indicates someone taking action on themselves. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate that the same person is both the subject and the object of the action. Alternate translation: [and becomes your slave] or [and sells himself into your service]

text: Let him stay with you as a hired worker or temporary resident; he is to work for you until the Year of Jubilee.
Then he and his children are to be released, and he may return to his clan and to the property of his fathers.
Because the Israelites are My servants, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt, they are not to be sold as slaves.

translation_challenges.note: The word translated as **For** indicates that what is follows is the reason for the instructions in [verses 39-43](../25/39.md). Use a natural way in your language to make this clear.

text: You are not to rule over them harshly, but you shall fear your God.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **harshness** is an abstract noun that refers to cruel or severe treatment. If your language does not use abstract nouns for the idea of **harshness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [or treat him harshly] or [or act cruelly toward him]
See how you translated this phrase in [25:36](../25/36.md). Alternate translation: [but you shall honor your God]

text: Your menservants and maidservants shall come from the nations around you, from whom you may purchase them.

translation_challenges.note: This introduces a new, but related, topic. If the connection between this statement and the previous one is not clear, you may want to use a different connecting word to show how this statement relates to what comes before it. Alternate translation: [As for your male slave]

These are generic nouns referring to any slaves in these categories. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And any of your male slaves or your female slaves … male slaves or female slaves]

text: You may also purchase them from the foreigners residing among you or their clans living among you who are born in your land. These may become your property.
You may leave them to your sons after you to inherit as property; you can make them slaves for life. But as for your brothers, the Israelites, no man may rule harshly over his brother.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this phrase in [25:43](../25/43.md). Alternate translation: [harshly]

text: If a foreigner residing among you prospers, but your countryman dwelling near him becomes destitute and sells himself to the foreigner or to a member of his clan,

translation_challenges.note: As you are translating [verses 47-55](../25/47.md) keep in mind that the situation described is that of an Israelite who has become a slave to a foreigner.
This entire verse is a hypothetical situation. Express this possible condition in a way that would be natural in your language.
See how you translated this common expression in [25:26](../25/26.md). Alternate translation: [a foreigner living among you becomes wealthy]

The words **sells himself** describes someone taking action on themselves. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate that the same person is both the subject and the object of the action. Alternate translation: [and becomes a slave] or [and sells himself into slavery]

text: he retains the right of redemption after he has sold himself. One of his brothers may redeem him:

translation_challenges.note: This means he can be freed by someone paying a price. Alternate translation: [he can be redeemed] or [someone can buy back his freedom]

text: either his uncle or cousin or any close relative from his clan may redeem him. Or if he prospers, he may redeem himself.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this idiom in [25:26](../25/26.md). Alternate translation: [he becomes prosperous]

This phrase describes someone taking action on themselves. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate that the same person is both the subject and the object of the action. Alternate translation: [then he may buy back his own freedom]

text: He and his purchaser will then count the time from the year he sold himself up to the Year of Jubilee. The price of his sale will be determined by the number of years, based on the daily wages of a hired hand.

translation_challenges.note: This phrase describes someone taking action on themselves. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate that the same person is both the subject and the object of the action. Alternate translation: [his becoming a slave]
Here, **to him** refers to the buyer. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [to the buyer]

Here, **the silver of his sale** refers to the price that he needs to pay to buy back his freedom. This price should be calculated based on the number of years remaining until the Year of Jubilee. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and the price that he needs to pay to buy back his freedom should be calculated by the number of years until the Year of Jubilee]

This compares the way to calculate the redemption price to how a hired worker is paid. Just as a hired worker is paid for the days he works, the redemption price should be based on the years of service remaining. Alternate translation: [The price should be calculated as if he were a hired worker being paid for those years]

text: If many years remain, he must pay for his redemption in proportion to his purchase price.

translation_challenges.note: Here, this describes how to calculate the price of freedom. The person must pay back part of the original purchase price, based on how many years are left until the Year of Jubilee. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state this explicitly. Alternate translation: [he must pay back the portion of the original purchase price that matches the remaining years of service] or [he must repay part of what the buyer paid for him, calculated according to the remaining years]

This refers to having many years remaining until the Year of Jubilee. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express this explicitly. Alternate translation: [many years remaining] or [many years left]

See how you translated this common expression in [25:16](../25/16.md). This expression means “according to” or “in proportion to.” Use a natural expression in your language that communicates this meaning. Alternate translation: [according to the number of years] or [based on the remaining years]

Here, this describes how to calculate the price of freedom. The person must pay back part of the original purchase price, based on how many years are left until the Year of Jubilee. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [he must pay back the portion of the original purchase price that matches the remaining years of service] or [he must repay part of what the buyer paid for him, calculated according to the remaining years]

text: If only a few years remain until the Year of Jubilee, he is to calculate and pay his redemption according to his remaining years.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this common expression in [25:51](../25/51.md). Alternate translation: [According to the number of years remaining]

text: He shall be treated like a man hired from year to year, but a foreign owner must not rule over him harshly in your sight.

translation_challenges.note: In the first sentence, **he** refers to the slave and **him** refers to the foreign buyer. In the second sentence, **He** refers to the foreign buyer and **him** refers to the slave. Alternate translation: [the slave shall be with the owner. The owner shall not rule over the slave]

Here, **before your eyes** means that the other Israelites are to watch how Israelite slaves are treated by their masters. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [under your supervision] or [while you watch]

text: Even if he is not redeemed in any of these ways, he and his children shall be released in the Year of Jubilee.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **sons** refers to children of both genders. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both male and female children. Alternate translation: [and his children]

text: For the Israelites are My servants. They are My servants, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt. I am the LORD your God.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **them** refers to the sons of Israel. In some languages, this pronoun may be redundant and can be omitted. Alternate translation: [the Israelites]

text: “You must not make idols for yourselves or set up a carved image or sacred pillar; you must not place a sculpted stone in your land to bow down to it. For I am the LORD your God.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **for I am Yahweh your God** gives the reason for the commands that precede it. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases. Alternate translation: [because I am Yahweh your God] or [Obey these commands because I am Yahweh your God]

text: You must keep My Sabbaths and have reverence for My sanctuary. I am the LORD.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this in [26:1](../26/01.md). Here, **I am Yahweh** gives the reason for the command. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a connecting word to make this relationship clear. Alternate translation: [because I am Yahweh]
This verse is identical to [19:30](../19/30.md). See how you translated it there.

text: If you follow My statutes and carefully keep My commandments,

translation_challenges.note: Here, **walk in my statutes** represents living according to God’s laws. Use a natural way in your language to express following or obeying laws. Alternate translation: [you live according to my laws]

These three phrases mean basically the same thing. The second and third phrases emphasize the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could combine these phrases and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [you completely and faithfully follow my rules]

text: I will give you rains in their season, and the land will yield its produce, and the trees of the field will bear their fruit.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **I will give** leaves out “to you” which is understood. If your language requires this information to be stated explicitly, include it. Alternate translation: [then I will give to you your rains in their time, and the land will give its produce to you, and the tree of the field will give its fruit to you]

Here, **the land** and **trees** are spoken of as if they were people who could give gifts. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and crops will grow in the land, and trees in the fields will produce fruit]

Here, **tree of the field** refers to any fruit-bearing tree and not a specific tree. Use a natural expression in your language that includes all such trees. Alternate translation: [and fruit trees will give their fruit] or [and trees that grow in your fields will give their fruit]

text: Your threshing will continue until the grape harvest, and the grape harvest will continue until sowing time; you will have your fill of food to eat and will dwell securely in your land.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **threshing will reach** means the harvests will be so abundant that one crop’s processing will overlap with the next harvest. Express this abundance clearly in your language. Alternate translation: [And you will have such abundant harvests that you will still be threshing grain when it is time to harvest grapes, and still be harvesting grapes when it is time to plant seeds]
Here, **seed** represents the activity of planting. Use a phrase that clearly refers to the planting season. Alternate translation: [planting time] or [the time to plant]

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **satisfaction** and **security**, you could express these ideas in a natural way in your language. Alternate translation: [until you are satisfied, and you will live safely]

text: And I will give peace to the land, and you will lie down with nothing to fear. I will rid the land of dangerous animals, and no sword will pass through your land.

translation_challenges.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express this in a natural way in your language. Alternate translation: [I will make things peaceful] or [I will cause you to live peacefully]

Here, **sword** represents war or armed conflict. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and there will be no war in your land] or [and no army will attack your land]

text: You will pursue your enemies, and they will fall by the sword before you.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **to your faces** means “before you” or “in front of you” in battle. Use an equivalent expression in your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when you attack them] or [before your attack]

Here, **fall … to the sword** is a common expression meaning to die in battle. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, use a comparable expression in your translation that does have that meaning, or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and they will die in battle before you] or [and they will be killed to your faces]

text: Five of you will pursue a hundred, and a hundred of you will pursue ten thousand, and your enemies will fall by the sword before you.

translation_challenges.note: These parallel statements are expressed in a poetic, proverbial way to emphasize how God will empower a small number to defeat many enemies. If your language has poetic or proverbial ways to express this kind of dramatic contrast, use them. Alternate translation: [Five will chase a hundred, a hundred will chase ten thousand] or express it as a proverb like [Your fives will scatter hundreds, your hundreds will scatter thousands]
See how you translated this in [26:7](../26/07.md). Here, **fall to your faces to the sword** means to die in battle.

text: I will turn toward you and make you fruitful and multiply you, and I will establish My covenant with you.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **I will turn to you** is a common expression meaning to show favor. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will favor you] or [I will bless you]

See how you translated this in [Genesis 1:28](../../gen/01/28.md). Here, **make you fruitful and multiply you** means to cause the people to have many children and descendants. Alternate translation: [and cause you to have many children and descendants]

text: You will still be eating the old supply of grain when you need to clear it out to make room for the new.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **old** is repeated three times to emphasize abundance, not staleness. Express this emphasis on abundance in a way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [You will still have plenty of last year’s grain when the new harvest comes]

Here, **from the face of** is a common expression meaning to make room for something. Use a natural way in your language to express making space available. Alternate translation: [to make room for the new grain] or [because you need space for the new crop]

Here, **old** and **new** leave out the word “grain” or “crop” which is understood. If your language requires this to be stated explicitly, include it. Alternate translation: [old grain … and … the old grain … the new grain] or [old crop … and … the old crop … the new crop]

text: And I will make My dwelling place among you, and My soul will not despise you.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **my soul** represents all of God. Use a natural way in your language to refer to the whole person. Alternate translation: [I] or [I, myself]

text: I will walk among you and be your God, and you will be My people.

translation_challenges.note: Here, this means “I will be your God and you will be my people.” If your language requires the relationship to be stated more explicitly, you can do so. Alternate translation: [I will be your God and you will be my people]

Here God is described as walking among his people like a person would. Use a natural way in your language to express God’s presence among people. Alternate translation: [I will live among you] or [I will be present with you]

text: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt so that you would no longer be slaves to the Egyptians. I broke the bars of your yoke and enabled you to walk in uprightness.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **bars of your yoke** represents slavery. Use a natural way in your language to express freedom from slavery. Alternate translation: [I freed you from slavery] or [I released you from bondage]

Here, **walk upright** represents freedom and dignity. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and made you free people] or [and gave you dignity]

text: If, however, you fail to obey Me and to carry out all these commandments,

translation_challenges.note: Here, **But if** introduces a contrast between [verses 3](../26/03.md) and [4](../26/04.md). Use a natural way in your language to show this contrast. Alternate translation: [However, if]

Here, **listen to** represents obedience. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression in your translation or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you will not obey me] or [you refuse to do what I say]

text: and if you reject My statutes, despise My ordinances, and neglect to carry out all My commandments, and so break My covenant,

translation_challenges.note: Here, **your soul** represents the whole person. If it would be helpful to your readers, use a natural way in your language to refer to the whole person. Alternate translation: [you detest] or [you hate]
If your language does not use abstract nouns for these ideas, you could express the same ideas in other ways.

text: then this is what I will do to you: I will bring upon you sudden terror, wasting disease, and fever that will destroy your sight and drain your life. You will sow your seed in vain, because your enemies will eat it.

translation_challenges.note: Here the repetition of **I** emphasizes that God will certainly act. Use a way in your language to show emphasis on God’s certain action. Alternate translation: [then I will certainly do]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **terror**, you could express this idea with a verb or adjective. Use a natural way in your language to express extreme fear. Alternate translation: [things that terrify you] or [frightening things]

Here the second phrase gives the reason for the first. Use a connecting word that makes it clear that what follows is the reason for what came before. Alternate translation: [You will plant your seed uselessly because your enemies will eat what grows]

Here this begins a section describing the results of disobedience. Use a natural way in your language to show this is the consequence of their actions. Alternate translation: [As a result, I will send] or [Because of this, I will bring]

text: And I will set My face against you, so that you will be defeated by your enemies. Those who hate you will rule over you, and you will flee when no one pursues you.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **set my face against** represents anger and opposition. Use a natural way in your language to express divine anger. Alternate translation: [I will oppose you] or [I will show my anger against you]
Here, **struck down** represents being killed. Use an equivalent expression for death or plain language in your translation. Alternate translation: [and you will be killed] or [and you will die]

Here, **to the face of** means “before” or “by” in battle. Use an equivalent expression or plain language to express being defeated by enemies. Alternate translation: [by your enemies] or [when your enemies attack you]
This verse describes the opposite situation from [verses 7-8](../26/07.md), where God’s people were victorious. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could make this contrast clear.

text: And if after all this you will not obey Me, I will proceed to punish you sevenfold for your sins.

translation_challenges.note: This means “if you still don’t obey after all this discipline.” Express this clearly in your language. Alternate translation: [If you still don’t obey me after all this punishment and] or [If you continue to disobey despite this discipline and]

Here, **seven times** could mean either complete punishment or greatly increased punishment. If you need to express the meaning of this expression in your language, consider following the interpretation of an accepted regional translation. Alternate translation: [completely] or [much more severely]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **sins**, you could express this as an action. Use a natural way in your language to express wrongdoing. Alternate translation: [your wrongdoing] or [your evil actions]

See how you translated this in [26:14](../26/14.md). Here, **listen to** represents obedience. Use a natural way in your language to express disobedience. Alternate translation: [you will not obey me] or [you refuse to do what I say]

text: I will break down your stubborn pride and make your sky like iron and your land like bronze,

translation_challenges.note: Here, **Then I will break the pride of your strength** introduces God’s goal for the discipline described in the rest of this verse and the next verse. He will make the heavens like iron and the land like bronze to humble the people. Express this purpose clearly in your language. Alternate translation: [And so I will make you humble] or [Because of this, I will destroy what makes you proud]

Here, **break** compares pride to something physical that can be broken, like a stick or rod. This represents how God will destroy their arrogance. Use a natural way in your language to express humbling someone. Alternate translation: [Then I will destroy your arrogance] or [Then I will take away what makes you proud]

These phrases **like iron** and **like bronze** compare the sky to iron and the land to bronze to show there will be no rain and the ground will be hard. Use natural comparisons in your language to express severe drought. Alternate translation: [the sky smooth as metal with no cloud blemishes and the ground as impenetrable to plant roots as metal]

This could mean either that they are very proud or that they are proud of their strength. Choose the interpretation that best fits your context. Alternate translation: [your strong pride] or [your pride in your power]

text: and your strength will be spent in vain. For your land will not yield its produce, and the trees of the land will not bear their fruit.

translation_challenges.note: This tells what will happen if the people continue to disobey. Use a natural way in your language to express this hypothetical situation. Alternate translation: [If you continue to disobey, then your strength will be used up for nothing] or [Then all your hard work will accomplish nothing]

The abstract concept **in vain** can be expressed as an action that produces no results. Use a natural way in your language to express futile effort. Alternate translation: [uselessly] or [without any result]

Here the **land** and **tree** are spoken of as if they were people who could give things. Use a natural way in your language to express failed crops. Alternate translation: [and nothing will grow in your land, and your trees will not produce any fruit] or [and nothing will grow in your land and on your trees]

text: If you walk in hostility toward Me and refuse to obey Me, I will multiply your plagues seven times, according to your sins.

translation_challenges.note: Many parts of this verse are similar to [verse 18](../26/18.md). See how you translated those parts in [26:18](../26/18.md).

Here, **walk with me in hostility** is speaking of how a person lives as if it were a way or path that a person was walking along. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you continue to oppose me] or [you persist in being hostile to me]

See how you translated this in [26:14](../26/14.md). Here, **listen to** represents obedience. Use a natural way in your language to express disobedience. Alternate translation: [and are not willing to obey me] or [and refuse to do what I say]
See how you translated this in [26:18](../26/18.md). Alternate translation: [much more severe]

See how you translated this in [26:18](../26/18.md). If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **sins**, it can be expressed as an action. Or you could use another way that is natural in your language to express wrongdoing. Alternate translation: [for your wrongdoing] or [for your evil actions]

text: I will send wild animals against you to rob you of your children, destroy your livestock, and reduce your numbers, until your roads lie desolate.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **animal of the field** is not referring to a specific animal. It means animals in general. If it would be helpful for your readers, use a general term for wild animals or specify if your language has different terms for various wild animals. Alternate translation: [wild animals] or [the animals of the field]

Here, **and it will bereave you** is a polite way of saying “they will kill your children.” Use a direct term for killing to avoid ambiguity. Alternate translation: [and it will kill your children] or [and it will wipe out your children]

text: And if in spite of these things you do not accept My discipline, but continue to walk in hostility toward Me,

translation_challenges.note: **And if by these things** introduces a condition that could happen similar to [verse 18](../26/18.md). Use a connecting structure that clearly indicates this condition. Alternate translation: [If by these things] or [And if these things happen and]

Here, **walk with me in hostility** is a metaphor for living in opposition to Yahweh. Use a natural expression in your language to convey ongoing opposition or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [but continue to oppose me] or [but live in opposition to me]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **discipline**, use an appropriate term in your language that conveys the concept of punishment or correction. Alternate translation: [my punishment] or [my correction]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **hostility**, use an appropriate term in your language that conveys the concept of opposition or enmity. Alternate translation: [in opposition] or [in enmity]

text: then I will act with hostility toward you, and I will strike you sevenfold for your sins.

translation_challenges.note: The intensive pronoun **myself** represents the pronoun “I” that God uses in the original even though the verbs translated as **walk** and **strike** already include this meaning. Doing this adds emphasis to what he is saying. If your language uses explicit pronouns for emphasis, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of bringing out this emphasis. Alternate translation: [then I will also walk … and I will also punish] or [then I myself will walk … and I will personally strike]

Here, **walk with you in hostility** is a common expression that means “living in opposition.” Use a comparable expression in your language to convey ongoing opposition or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will continue to oppose you] or [I will persist in being hostile towards you]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **hostility**, you could express the same idea in another way to convey the concept of opposition or enmity. Alternate translation: [then I, I also will walk hostilely with you]

The phrase **strike you seven times** is a common expression indicating either greatly increased punishment or complete punishment. Choose the interpretation that fits your context. Alternate translation: [and I will strike you completely for your sins] or [and I will punish you sevenfold for your sins]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **sins**, you could express this idea in another way that conveys wrongdoing. Alternate translation: [because you sinned]

text: And I will bring a sword against you to execute the vengeance of the covenant. Though you withdraw into your cities, I will send a plague among you, and you will be delivered into the hand of the enemy.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **a sword** represents “war.” Use an equivalent expression or plain language that appropriately conveys war. Alternate translation: [I will bring war upon you] or [I will wage war against you]

Here, **a sword** is spoken of as if it were a living thing that could be an agent of vengeance. Use a natural expression in your language that conveys the idea or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the avenging sword of] or [the sword which acts in avenging]

Here, **avenging the vengeance of the covenant** uses parallelism for emphasis. Use a similar parallel structure if it would be helpful to your readers, or express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [punishing according to the covenant’s vengeance]

Here, **the vengeance of the covenant** refers to the curses associated with violating the covenant. Use your language’s term for these consequences. Alternate translation: [the covenant’s curses] or [the curses of the covenant]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **vengeance**, you could express the same idea in a way that conveys punishment in your language. Alternate translation: [the punishments of] or [the retributions of]

If your language does not use a passive form like **and you will be gathered into your cities**, you could express the same idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and you will gather to hide in your cities]

Here, **and you will be gathered into your cities** means that people will flee to their cities for safety. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and you will flee to your cities to seek safety] or [and you will gather in your cities for protection]

Here, **And I will send pestilence** connects to the previous clause to show continued discipline. Use a connecting word to show how this statement relates to what comes before it. Alternate translation: [Furthermore, I will send pestilence] or [Moreover, I will send pestilence]

The expression **you will be given into the hand of an enemy** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [and I will give you into the hand of an enemy]

Here, **the hand of an enemy** represents being captured or killed by the enemy. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and you will be captured by the enemy] or [and you will be killed by the enemy]
Here, **an enemy** is not referring to a specific enemy but enemies in general. Use a general term for enemies.

text: When I cut off your supply of bread, ten women will bake your bread in a single oven and dole out your bread by weight, so that you will eat but not be satisfied.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **the staff of bread** is a common expression meaning “famine.” Use a comparable expression from your language that conveys the same meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [When I cause famine] or [When I bring famine upon you]

Here, **then ten women will bake your bread in one oven** implies severe food scarcity. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [then ten women will bake your bread in one oven due to scarcity] or [then ten women will bake your bread in a single oven because of famine]

Here, **and they will return your bread by weight** means that bread will be distributed carefully to families. Use an expression that conveys precise distribution. Alternate translation: [and they will carefully measure and distribute your bread to their families] or [and they will return your bread in measured portions to their families]

Here, **but not be satisfied** shows a contrast between expectation and reality, indicating that people will not be content despite receiving some bread. In your translation, indicate this contrast in a way that is natural in your language . Alternate translation: [but you will not be satisfied] or [yet you will not be content]

text: But if in spite of all this you do not obey Me, but continue to walk in hostility toward Me,

translation_challenges.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **hostility**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [as my enemy] or [by rebelling against me]

text: then I will walk in fury against you, and I, even I, will punish you sevenfold for your sins.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **in the heat of hostility** is an expression comparing strong feelings of hostility to the intensity of a fire. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [amid strong hostility] or [in the midst of fierce opposition]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **hostility**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [opposition] or [enmity]

The intensive pronoun **myself** represents the pronoun “I” that God uses in the original even though the verb translated as **discipline** already includes this meaning. Doing this adds emphasis to what he is saying. If your language uses explicit pronouns for emphasis, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of bringing out this emphasis. Alternate translation: [and I will personally discipline you seven times]

text: You will eat the flesh of your own sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [And you will eat the flesh of your sons and daughters]

text: I will destroy your high places, cut down your incense altars, and heap your lifeless bodies on the lifeless remains of your idols; and My soul will despise you.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **my soul** represents the speaker (Yahweh). Use a natural expression in your language that maintains the emphasis on personal detestation. Alternate translation: [and my soul will hate you] or [and I will deeply despise you]

text: I will reduce your cities to rubble and lay waste your sanctuaries, and I will refuse to smell the pleasing aroma of your sacrifices.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **pleasing aromas** represents sacrifices, as God often refers to the pleasant smells of burnt offerings and incense. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the pleasant scents of your sacrifices] or [the delightful aromas of your offerings]

text: And I will lay waste the land, so that your enemies who dwell in it will be appalled.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this in [26:16](../26/16.md). Alternate translation: [I will also make the land desolate] or [I, myself, will make the land desolate]

Here, the connector **and** implies that the reason that the enemies will be appalled is because the land is so desolate. If the connection between this statement and the previous one is not clear, you may want to use a different connecting word to show how this statement relates to what comes before it. Alternate translation: [furthermore, your enemies who dwell in it will be appalled] or [additionally, your enemies residing there will be appalled]

text: But I will scatter you among the nations and will draw out a sword after you as your land becomes desolate and your cities are laid waste.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **a sword** represents war. Use a term that appropriately conveys war or conflict in your language. Alternate translation: [and I will wage war against you] or [and I will bring war upon you]

text: Then the land shall enjoy its Sabbaths all the days it lies desolate, while you are in the land of your enemies. At that time the land will rest and enjoy its Sabbaths.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **the land** is spoken of as if it were a living thing that could rest and enjoy its sabbaths. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the land will observe its sabbaths and rest … the land will honor its sabbaths by resting]

text: As long as it lies desolate, the land will have the rest it did not receive during the Sabbaths when you lived in it.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **what it did not rest in your sabbaths** means that the land will rest in compensation for the sabbaths the Israelites did not observe. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [what it did not rest during your sabbaths] or [the land will rest for the sabbaths you neglected]

text: As for those of you who survive, I will send a faintness into their hearts in the lands of their enemies, so that even the sound of a windblown leaf will put them to flight. And they will flee as one flees the sword, and fall when no one pursues them.

translation_challenges.note: This indicates that as for those who survive, Yahweh will bring additional discipline. Use a grammatical structure that clearly connects the survival of some people with the forthcoming actions. Alternate translation: [As for those of you who survive, I will bring] or [And for the remaining among you, I will bring]

Here, **their heart** represents where a person’s thoughts, feelings, and fears exist. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [fearfulness into their hearts] or [deep anxiety within them]

Here, **their heart** shifts Yahweh’s perspective from addressing the survivors directly to speaking about them in the third person. Follow a clear and natural use of pronouns in your language. Alternate translation: [within their hearts] or [inside their hearts]

Here, **the sound of a driven leaf** is spoken of as a living thing actively chasing people. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [The sound of a blowing leaf will pursue them] or [The noise of a driven leaf will chase after them]

The expression **a driven leaf** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use this form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [a leaf that the wind drives] or [a leaf that the wind blows]

Here, **a sword** represents a person who is going to harm them. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [a warrior] or [an aggressor]

text: They will stumble over one another as before the sword, though no one is behind them. So you will not be able to stand against your enemies.

translation_challenges.note: This is a common expression in the writer’s culture that describes people falling over each other in panic while trying to flee. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [They will fall over each other while running away] or [They will trip over one another as they flee]

Here, **from the face of** is a common expression of the culture meaning “before” or “in front of.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as from before a sword] or [as from someone threatening them with a sword]

The point of this comparison is that just as people flee from an armed enemy, so will these people flee even though no one is actually pursuing them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [as if someone were chasing them with a sword] or [like people running from an armed enemy]

Here, **power to stand** means to successfully resist or fight back against enemies. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [strength to resist] or [ability to defend yourselves]
See how you translated this expression earlier in this verse. Here it means “before” or “against.” Alternate translation: [against your enemies] or [when your enemies attack]

The text shifts from talking about the people in the third person (**they**) to addressing them directly (**you**). If it would be helpful for your readers, you could use the same pronoun throughout. Alternate translation: [And you will stumble … you will have] or [And they will stumble … they will have]

text: You will perish among the nations, and the land of your enemies will consume you.

translation_challenges.note: This talks about **the land of your enemies** as if it were a living thing that could consume people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and the land of your enemies will devour you]

text: Those of you who survive in the lands of your enemies will waste away in their iniquity and will decay in the sins of their fathers.

translation_challenges.note: This could mean: 1) they will not prosper spiritually, 2) they will not prosper materially, and 3) they will literally die, and their bodies will rot away. Try to use a term broad enough to cover all three meanings in your language. Alternate translation: [will perish … they will perish] or [will decay … they will decay]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **iniquity** or **iniquities**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [in their sins … in the sins of] or [in their wrongdoings … in the wrongdoings of]

Here, **fathers** represents ancestors. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [their ancestors] or [their forefathers]

text: But if they will confess their iniquity and that of their fathers in the unfaithfulness that they practiced against Me, by which they have also walked in hostility toward Me—

translation_challenges.note: Here, **And they confess** introduces a strong contrast. In your translation, indicate this contrast in a way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [But if they confess] or [However, if they confess]

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **iniquity**, **unfaithfulness**, and **hostility**, you could express those same ideas in another way. Alternate translation: [the ways they sinned and the ways their ancestors sinned and did not faithfully obey me … hostilely]
Here, **fathers** represents ancestors. See how you translated this in [26:39](../26/39.md). Alternate translation: [their ancestors] or [their forefathers]
See how you translated this in [26:21](../26/21.md). Alternate translation: [they lived in hostility]

text: and I acted with hostility toward them and brought them into the land of their enemies—and if their uncircumcised hearts will be humbled and they will make amends for their iniquity,

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this repetition in [26:16](../26/16.md). Alternate translation: [I, too, walked]
See how you translated this in [26:24](../26/24.md). Alternate translation: [I walked with hostility toward them]

The expression **their uncircumcised heart is humbled** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [they humble their uncircumcised hearts]

Here, **heart** represents where a person’s emotions, feelings, and desires exist, and the **uncircumcised heart** represents people who are unwilling to obey God. Since physical circumcision was a sign of being in covenant with God, an uncircumcised heart represents resistance to God’s covenant. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [their stubborn inner nature] or [their rebellious attitude]

This could mean either: 1) they accept the punishment that their wrongdoing deserves, or 2) they acknowledge and admit their guilt. If you can translate this in a way that can capture both meanings do that, otherwise you could follow how your local major language translations understand this phrase. Alternate translation: [they accept their punishment] or [they admit their guilt]

text: then I will remember My covenant with Jacob and My covenant with Isaac and My covenant with Abraham, and I will remember the land.

For the land will be abandoned by them, and it will enjoy its Sabbaths by lying desolate without them. And they will pay the penalty for their iniquity, because they rejected My ordinances and abhorred My statutes.

translation_challenges.note: The expression **And the land will be deserted by them** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And they will desert the land, and the land will enjoy] or [And they will leave the land deserted, and it will enjoy]
The pronoun **them** refers to the Israelites who will be taken away from the land. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [by the Israelites] or [by those people]

Here, **in its desolation from them** implies that the land is empty without them. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [while it is empty without them] or [as it becomes desolate without them]

Here, the repetition of **they** shifts focus from the land to the people. Use a way that is natural in your language to make this clear. Alternate translation: [And they will accept] or [They, they will accept]
See how you translated this in [26:41](../26/41.md). Here it seems more clear that they are accepting the punishment for their wrongdoing. Alternate translation: [they accept their punishment]

Here, **because, even because** emphatically marks the reason for the result that came before. If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [because] or [even because]

text: Yet in spite of this, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject or despise them so as to destroy them and break My covenant with them; for I am the LORD their God.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **for I am Yahweh their God** provides a reason for the result. If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of this phrase to appear at the beginning of the sentence. Alternate translation: [because I am Yahweh their God] or [since I am Yahweh their God]

text: But for their sake I will remember the covenant with their fathers, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt in the sight of the nations, that I might be their God. I am the LORD.”

translation_challenges.note: Here, **the covenant of the first** refers to “the first covenant” or “the covenant with the first generation of Israelites”. You could use a comparable expression that accurately reflects this meaning in your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the first covenant with them] or [the covenant with the first generation of Israelites]

Here, the phrase **to the eyes of the nations** represents the people that observed God’s actions. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in the sight of the nations] or [before the nations]

Here, **to be God to them** represents the goal or purpose of bringing them out of Egypt. Use an expression in your language that makes it clear that this is the purpose. Alternate translation: [to serve as their God] or [to be their God]

text: These are the statutes, ordinances, and laws that the LORD established between Himself and the Israelites through Moses on Mount Sinai.

translation_challenges.note: This verse provides a closing summary of at least [chapters 17-26](../17/01.md), if not an initial closing for the entire book. Use the natural form in your language for expressing the conclusion to the previous section.

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **the statutes and the judgments and the laws**, you could express the same ideas in different ways. Alternate translation: [the commands, rules, and instructions] or [all that God commanded and instructed]

Here, **between him and between the sons of Israel on Mount Sinai by the hand of Moses** means that this covenant agreement, which consisted of the statutes, judgments, and laws, was made between Yahweh and the Israelites on Mount Sinai with Moses as mediator and scribe. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [to the Israelites at Mount Sinai, which Moses wrote down as their mediator]

Here, **by the hand of Moses** represents Moses acting as a mediator and scribe. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [through Moses as mediator] or [with Moses serving as mediator and writing these things down]

text: Then the LORD said to Moses,
“Speak to the Israelites and say to them, ‘When someone makes a special vow to the LORD involving the value of persons,

translation_challenges.note: In Hebrew, they introduced speech by using two similar phrases. If this kind of repetition would not be natural in your language, you could combine them. Alternate translation: [Say to the sons of Israel]
Here, **sons of Israel** refers to the entire Israelite people, not just the male descendants or the original 12 sons of Jacob. Alternate translation: [the people of Israel] or [the Israelites]

Here, **a man** refers to any person, not a specific man. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Anyone] or [Any person]

This is a common expression meaning to make a special kind of vow. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he makes a special vow] or [he makes a solemn promise]

The phrase **your valuation** occurs 19 times in the chapter. For people, the valuation is set here by Yahweh. For more information see the introduction to [chapter 5](../05/01.md) and how you you translated this in [5:15](../05/15.md). Alternate translation: [by the valuation of persons that I, Yahweh, give you]

text: if the valuation concerns a male from twenty to sixty years of age, then your valuation shall be fifty shekels of silver, according to the sanctuary shekel.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **son of** is a common expression in the culture which refers to a person who has some characteristic. In this instance, it is referring to males who have age ranges from 20-59. If this would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from age twenty to age fifty-nine]

In ancient times the silver **shekel of the holy place** was the standard weight kept by the priests in the Dwelling and later the temple. Alternate translation: [according to the standard shekel kept at the holy place]

text: Or if it is a female, then your valuation shall be thirty shekels.

translation_challenges.note: The ages from [verse 3](../27/03.md), (twenty to fifty-nine years) carry over to this verse. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And if it is a female between twenty and fifty-nine years old]

text: And if the person is from five to twenty years of age, then your valuation for the male shall be twenty shekels, and for the female ten shekels.

translation_challenges.note: This is a common expression referring to ages 5-19. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from age five to age nineteen]

text: Now if the person is from one month to five years of age, then your valuation for the male shall be five shekels of silver, and for the female three shekels of silver.

translation_challenges.note: This is a common expression referring to ages one month to four years. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from one month old to four years old]

text: And if the person is sixty years of age or older, then your valuation shall be fifteen shekels for the male and ten shekels for the female.

translation_challenges.note: This is a common expression referring to ages sixty and older. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [sixty years old and older]

text: But if the one making the vow is too poor to pay the valuation, he is to present the person before the priest, who shall set the value according to what the one making the vow can afford.

translation_challenges.note: Here **too poor from your valuation** means unable to pay the standard amount. You could make this explicit in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And if he is too poor to pay the standard valuation]

Here, **he** refers to the person making the vow (who is poor), and **him** refers to the person that has been promised to Yahweh that the vower is trying to redeem. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [then the person making the vow shall present the one promised to Yahweh]

Here, **before the face of the priest** represents being in front of the priest. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in front of the priest] or [in the priest’s presence]

This is a common expression meaning according to what someone can pay. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Based on how much the one making the vow can afford]

text: If he vows an animal that may be brought as an offering to the LORD, any such animal given to the LORD shall be holy.

translation_challenges.note: The meaning of this verse may be unclear due to its complex structure. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation, if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And if someone is presenting a portion of an animal as an offering to Yahweh]

text: He must not replace it or exchange it, either good for bad or bad for good. But if he does substitute one animal for another, both that animal and its substitute will be holy.

translation_challenges.note: The words **exchange** and **substitute** mean very similar things and are used together for emphasis. If your language would not use two similar words this way, you could combine them into a single clear expression. Alternate translation: [He must not trade it for another animal]

Some words are left out that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You could supply these words from the context if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [not a good animal for a worse one or a bad animal for a better one]

This Hebrew expression uses repetition of the verb “substitute” to intensify the idea. If your language does not repeat words for intensification, you could have another way of expressing the same idea. Alternate translation: [And if indeed he substitutes]

text: But if the vow involves any of the unclean animals that may not be brought as an offering to the LORD, the animal must be presented before the priest.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **to the face of** represents being in front of the person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of the priest] or [in the priest’s presence]

text: The priest shall set its value, whether high or low; as the priest values it, the price will be set.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **your valuation** refers to the value that the priest determines for the poor person’s offering. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [The value that you, the priest, determine]

text: If, however, the owner decides to redeem the animal, he must add a fifth to its value.

translation_challenges.note: This Hebrew expression **redeeming he will redeem it** uses repetition to intensify expression of the idea. If your language does not repeat words for intensification, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [indeed he redeems it]
See how you translated this in [5:16](../05/16.md).

text: Now if a man consecrates his house as holy to the LORD, then the priest shall value it either as good or bad. The price will stand just as the priest values it.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **a man** refers to any person, not a specific man. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Anyone] or [Any person]

The phrase **between good and between bad** means the priest will assess the condition of the house to determine its value. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [according to the condition of the house]

text: But if he who consecrated his house redeems it, he must add a fifth to the assessed value, and it will belong to him.

translation_challenges.note: In the phrase **the one consecrating**, the words “his house” are left out but understood from the previous verse. You could supply these words if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [the one consecrating his house]
See how you translated this in [27:13](../27/13.md).

Here, **and it will be to him** is a common expression meaning that ownership will be transferred to him. You could use a comparable expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and it will belong to him]

Here, **your valuation** refers to the value that the priest determined based on the condition of the house. You could say that explicitly if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the value you determined]

text: If a man consecrates to the LORD a parcel of his land, then your valuation shall be proportional to the seed required for it—fifty shekels of silver for every homer of barley seed.

translation_challenges.note: The phrase **field of his possession** refers to inherited property that was originally given to Israelite families when they entered Canaan. This property generally returned to the family every 49 years at Jubilee. Alternate translation: [from his inherited field]

This means the amount of seed. It could mean either 1) the amount of seed needed to plant the field or 2) the amount of seed the field produces. Alternate translation: [according to how much seed it takes to plant] or [according to how much seed to produce]

A **homer** was a unit of volume that may have been about 220 liters. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurement. Alternate translation: [about 220 liters of]

text: If he consecrates his field during the Year of Jubilee, the price will stand according to your valuation.
But if he consecrates his field after the Jubilee, the priest is to calculate the price in proportion to the years left until the next Year of Jubilee, so that your valuation will be reduced.

translation_challenges.note: The phrase **upon the mouth of the years** is a common expression meaning based on the number of years. You could use a comparable expression from your language that has the same meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [according to the number of years]

text: And if the one who consecrated the field decides to redeem it, he must add a fifth to the assessed value, and it shall belong to him.

translation_challenges.note: The phrase **redeeming he will redeem** uses repetition to intensify the idea. If your language does not use repetition for intensification, you could use another way that is natural in your language to convey this meaning. Alternate translation: [if indeed he redeems]
See how you translated this in [27:13](../27/13.md).

The phrase **it will stand to him** is a common expression meaning ownership will revert to him. You could use a comparable expression from your language that has the same meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and it will belong to him again]

text: If, however, he does not redeem the field, or if he has sold it to another man, it may no longer be redeemed.

translation_challenges.note: This verse presents a case where someone tries to profit twice from the same field by dedicating it and then selling it. As a result, they lose the right to the field permanently. You could say this explicitly if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [he will permanently lose the right to redeem it]

The expression **it shall not be redeemed again** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [no one will be able to redeem it again]

text: When the field is released in the Jubilee, it will become holy, like a field devoted to the LORD; it becomes the property of the priests.

translation_challenges.note: This is a common expression referring to when property ownership changes at the Year of Jubilee. You could use a natural expression in your language that has the same meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when ownership transfers in the Year of Jubilee]

A **field of devotion** refers to land that is completely and permanently dedicated to Yahweh. This is a stronger term than “consecrated.” You could use a term in your language that communicates this permanent, irrevocable dedication. Alternate translation: [as a field permanently and completely given to Yahweh]

text: Now if a man consecrates to the LORD a field he has purchased, which is not a part of his own property,

translation_challenges.note: The phrase **a field of his purchase** refers to a field someone has bought rather than inherited. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [a field that he has purchased]

A **field of possession** refers to inherited land that was originally given to Israelite families. You could state this explicitly if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [which is not part of his inherited family land]

text: then the priest shall calculate for him the value up to the Year of Jubilee, and the man shall pay the assessed value on that day as a sacred offering to the LORD.
In the Year of Jubilee the field shall return to the one from whom it was bought—the original owner of the land.

translation_challenges.note: Here both instances of **him** refer to the original owner who has inheritance rights, while **he** refers to the person who bought and then dedicated the field. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [to the original owner from whom the buyer bought it, to whom]

This refers to the person who permanently owns the land through inheritance rights. You could say this explicitly, if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [to the one who permanently owns the land by inheritance]

text: Every valuation will be according to the sanctuary shekel, twenty gerahs to the shekel.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this in [27:3](../27/03.md).
A **gerah** was a unit of weight equal to about one-half gram. You could use a known unit of weight in your language. Alternate translation: [units each equal to about one-half gram]

text: But no one may consecrate a firstborn of the livestock, because a firstborn belongs to the LORD. Whether it is an ox or a sheep, it is the LORD’s.

translation_challenges.note: The assumption is that readers will know that Yahweh automatically owns all firstborn animals from the time of the Passover, so no one can consecrate them. You could say that explicitly if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [no one may consecrate a firstborn animal to Yahweh, whether ox or sheep, because all firstborn animals already belong to Yahweh]

text: But if it is among the unclean animals, then he may redeem it according to your valuation and add a fifth of its value. If it is not redeemed, then it shall be sold according to your valuation.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this in [27:13](../27/13.md)

The phrase **if it is not redeemed, then it shall be sold** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And if no one redeems it, then you must sell it at the value you determined]

text: Nothing that a man sets apart to the LORD from all he owns—whether a man, an animal, or his inherited land—can be sold or redeemed; everything so devoted is most holy to the LORD.

translation_challenges.note: A **devoted thing** refers to something that is completely and permanently dedicated to Yahweh. This is a stronger term than “consecrated.” See how you translated this in [27:21](../27/21.md). Alternate translation: [thing permanently and completely given to Yahweh]

This refers to anything someone might own that could be devoted to Yahweh. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [whether a person, an animal, or an inherited field]
See how you translated this in [2:3](../02/03.md).

text: No person set apart for destruction may be ransomed; he must surely be put to death.

translation_challenges.note: All **devoted ones** refers to someone who is completely and permanently dedicated to Yahweh. When someone is **devoted to destruction**, it means they must be executed because they are enemies of Israel or have severely broken Yahweh’s covenant. Alternate translation: [people who must be executed because they are permanently condemned]

If your language does not use a passive verbal form in this way, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [All those whom Yahweh has condemned to death]

The expression **shall not be ransomed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use this form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [no one may pay to save their lives]

The expression **he shall be put to death** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must certainly execute them]

text: Thus any tithe from the land, whether from the seed of the land or the fruit of the trees, belongs to the LORD; it is holy to the LORD.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **seed** represents all food crops that grow from seeds. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the crops of the land] or [from what grows in the fields]

text: If a man wishes to redeem part of his tithe, he must add a fifth to its value.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated a similar phrase about redeeming property in [27:19](../27/19.md). Alternate translation: [indeed someone redeems part of his tithe]

text: Every tenth animal from the herd or flock that passes under the shepherd’s rod will be holy to the LORD.

translation_challenges.note: This is a common expression that refers to how shepherds would count their animals by making them pass under a rod one by one. You could use a comparable expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [all that is counted in the flock]

text: He must not inspect whether it is good or bad, and he shall not make any substitution. But if he does make a substitution, both the animal and its substitute shall become holy; they cannot be redeemed.’”

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this in [27:10](../27/10.md). Alternate translation: [He must not inspect them to trade a good one for a bad one]

The phrase **It shall not be redeemed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use this form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [No one may redeem it]

text: These are the commandments that the LORD gave to Moses for the Israelites on Mount Sinai.
